parts of the oragnism, and which, escaping from it, through its marginal
pores, will go forth to lay the foundation for new disks elsewhere.

43  Besides these, however, I have more rarely met with certain other
bodies, apparently imbedded in the sarcode, which may be either
"gemmules" in a later<s>st</s> stage, or may probably be two <u>ova</u>; these,
represented in Plate I, Fig 11, seem to exhibit various stages of binary
subdivision; and they present a deep-red colour, even in spirit
specimens. I can scarcely imagine that these can be vegetable
organisms, that have been introduced through the marginal pores;
since they are much too large to pass through these, without a great alteration
in form; and this would seem to be incompatible with the firmness of their envelope. If <s>g</s> Fig. 11, is represented, under the
same magnifying power with the foregoing, an object which I have
detected in one of my vertical sections of the shell, where it
occupies one of the superficial cells, the cover of which is
deficient. Now it is quite probable that this cell may have
been accidentally abraded, and that the object in question may
have found its way into it <u>ab externo</u>: its position and aspect, however,
seem to me much more conformable to the idea, that it has been developed
